causes: Tang Dynasty sought control over Silk Road trade routes.
Khotan allied with the Tibetan Empire, resisting Tang authority.
General Gao Xianzhi led a Chinese campaign to bring the region under Tang rule.
events_leading_up_to_war: Tang military victories in Central Asia emboldened their expansion.
Khotan resisted Tang influence and supported Tibetan incursions.
China launched a full-scale military campaign to subdue Khotan.

result.general: Tang Dynasty victory; Khotan brought under Tang rule.
result.territorial_changes: Khotan and surrounding regions became vassals of Tang China.

Tang_Dynasty.troops: 30,000+ soldiers, including cavalry and auxiliary forces
Tang_Dynasty.weapons: Composite bows, swords, crossbows, siege equipment

major_battles.name: Battle of Khotan
major_battles.description: Tang forces under Gao Xianzhi besieged and stormed Khotan, crushing local resistance.

texts.name: Tang Annals
texts.details: Describes Gao Xianzhi's campaigns in Central Asia.

archaeological_evidence.description: Records found in Dunhuang detailing garrison reports from the region.
Evidence of Chinese influence on Khotanese culture post-war.

political: Khotan was integrated into the Tang protectorate system.
Weakened Tibetan influence in the Tarim Basin.
long_term_effects: Boosted Chinese control over Silk Road trade.
Set the stage for future clashes with Tibet and Arab forces.

military: Highlighted Tang China's military reach deep into Central Asia.
Used cavalry and siege tactics to dominate local kingdoms.
political: Expanded Chinese power over key trade routes.
Strengthened Tang diplomatic relations with other Central Asian states.
cultural: Spread Chinese administrative practices into Central Asia.
Influenced Buddhist art and culture in the region.
